stem: The hospital discharge coordinator is discussing placement options with four clients. Based on the documentation, match each client with the most appropriate post-acute facility.

tabs.title: Client Information
tabs.content:
Patient A: 45-year-old with Spinal Cord Injury (SCI). Stable, requires 3 hours of physical/occupational therapy daily to regain function.
Patient B: 82-year-old with hip fracture. Recovering, requires assistance with all ADLs and daily wound care.
Patient C: 72-year-old with terminal pancreatic cancer. Family unable to provide care at home.
Patient D: 65-year-old with mild dementia. Lives alone, leaves stove on; needs safe environment, no daily medical needs.

tabs.title: Additional Information
tabs.content: Patient D: Widowed, previously lived in a multi-story home.

rows.text: Client needing intense therapy (3+ hours/day) for recovery
Client needing continuous nursing care for wound management and ADLs
Client needing end-of-life care with a prognosis of < 6 months
Client needing a supervised residential setting for safety and social needs

rationale.correct: Inpatient Rehab (IRF) (c1) requires patients to tolerate intense therapy (r1). Skilled Nursing (SNF) (c2) provides medical nursing care for those who can't go home yet (r2). Hospice (c3) is for end-of-life care (r3). Assisted Living (ALF) (c4) is for residential safety, not medical treatment (r4).
clinicalPearls: IRF = Intense Rehabilitation (3+ hours of therapy).
SNF = Skilled Nursing (Medical care and ADL assistance).
ALF = Assisted Living (Help with ADLs, but relatively independent).
Hospice = End-of-life care focused on comfort and dignity.

questionTrap.trap: Sending a confused elderly patient to Inpatient Rehab.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Assess the patient's ability to tolerate intense therapy. If they cannot, a SNF is more appropriate.

mnemonic.title: Post-Acute Care Facilities
mnemonic.expansion: IRF: Intense Rehab; SNF: Skilled Nursing; ALF: Assisted Living; Hospice: Home for the end.
